title: Potential Credential Dumping Via Certipy
id: d40b0920-957d-405d-9486-84750d983f29
status: test
description: |
    Detects using the "Certipy" tool for credential dumping.
    "Certipy" is an offensive python script which uses "pywin32" to dump credentials of all the logon sessions on the local host.
    A "certificate" is created and stored in a folder with the name of the user's SID, which can then be copied and used on other hosts.
    "Certipy" was used in the EternalBlue and ShadowBroken attacks.

    - https://github.com/OffSecPro/certipy

references:

logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        Image|endswith: '\MouseLock.exe'
    # This detection rule might be improved.
    # It's just a starting point, which can be used as a starting point to a more specific one.
    # The only problem is, that there is no good way of detecting the cursor movement without this suspicious command line parameter.
    # On the other hand, using this command line parameter with the wrong parameters is also not possible.
    # The detection should be able to be used for any legit program with the 'MouseLock.exe' file, which is not a builtin program
    # but located in the SysWOW64 directory, which means it could also be used by a malware.
    # The legitimate programs would not have a suspicious command line parameters
    # because that's exactly the reason why this detection is built (to detect such programs)
    # so it's better to use the suspicious command line parameters and not a list of legit programs
    # this might improve the detection later
    # it also can lead to detection issues if the legit program has the same command line parameters as a suspicious one
    # this detection rule only covers the "MouseLock.exe" builtin program (in the SysWOW64 directory),
    # not any other ones
    # and the "MouseLock.exe" builtin program does not have any suspicious command line parameters.
    # so the detection should be able to be used for any other program with the "MouseLock.exe" builtin program
    # as long as they are in the same location (SysWOW64 directory)
    # this detection rule can be used to detect legit programs which are also located in the SysWOW64 directory
    # the legit programs might have suspicious command line parameters and can be used to execute arbitrary code.
    # this detection rule might be useful in a more specific one,
    # to detect the legit program which is located in the SysWOW64 directory
    # and which has suspicious command line parameters which can be used to execute arbitrary code
    # for more specific one, use the "process_cmdline" flag instead
    # and use the "Image" attribute (or "OriginalFileName" or "ParentProcessName") instead of the "process_cmdline" attribute
    # to have more information about the program used by the "MouseLock.exe" builtin program
    # the "OriginalFileName" attribute can be used to display the full path of the program
    # the "ParentProcessName" attribute can be used to display the parent program name
    # (which could be a legit program or a process created by a legit program or a process created by malware)
    # and both of them can be used to know if the program is legit or malicious
    # if the program is legit and not suspicious
    # and it's not created by malware
    # the parent program can be either a legit program or a process created by a legit program
    # or a process created by malware
    # and the suspicious command line parameter might be removed later
    # in order to improve the detection quality and not mis

    This is often used in order to store credentials and other data that could be used in a ransomware attack.

Detects the execution of the WinDbg debugger, the PE inside this debugger is signed and can be used as a indicator for a debugging activity.


### Signatures:

Signature | Description | Status | 
--------- | ----------- | ------ | 
a9e7c924-1892-407d-b5e8-721866922c67 | FileName + OriginalFileName, ImageMd5, CRC, SHA1, SHA256 5 / 6


### How to implement the detection rule:

Only the 6 signatures are checked (5 of the 6 have a value) the others will always return false.

In order to filter the different signatures one must use the `any_of` condition

---

Detects execution of the "te.exe" utility, which is used for extracting information from files and archives (e. g..exe,.dll,.sys,.cab,.msi) and libraries (e. g..mui).

Input arguments and image file are used for filtering.


### ðŸŽ¯  Goal

Determine potential uses of the "te.exe" utility.


### ðŸ“–  Implementation details

This implementation relies on 3'selectors':

- "Image" containing "te.exe"
- "Image" ending with "te.exe"
- "CommandLine" containing "te.exe"

This allows to filter out potentially useless data, such as a logon process or command lines that are not related to the "te.exe" utility.


### ðŸ—ƒ  Dataset

The following files are needed for this module:

- te.exe
- te.dll

All files can be obtained by downloading the toolset from https://github.com/LOLBAS-Project/ import it in the Lolbas project.

### ðŸ›   Required Enviroment Variables

- None required

### ðŸ”©  Attack Commands



### ðŸ”¹  @n3wjack :

```js
var parent = "Image" : endswith : ".exe"
  var child = "Image" : contains : "te.exe"
  var args = "CommandLine" : contains : "te.exe"

  group_1 = input : child
  group_2 = input : parent
  group_3 = input : args

  selection :
    parents :
      contains :
        title : 'Group_1'
    children :
      endswith :
        title : 'Group_2'
    args :
      contains :
        title : 'Group_3'

  filter_image :
    parents :
      contains :
        title : 'Group_1'
        command_line :
          contains :
            'te.exe'
    children :
      endswith :
        title : 'Group_2'
        image :
          endswith :
            'te.exe'
    args :
      contains :
        title : 'Group_3'
        command_line :
          contains :
            'te.exe'


  condition :
    all_of :

description: Detects suspicious binary compilation based on the 'pdb' and 'pdbstr' command-line arguments.
references:
    - https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/scientific-research/220160632126
author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)
date: 2021-11-26
modified: 2023-02-05
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.t1564.001
    - attack.s0105
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - pdbstr.exe
            - 'pdbstr'
            - 'c'
        CommandLine|contains|any:
            - 'compile'
            - 'pdb'
    condition: all of selection
falsepositives:
    - Legitimate developers
    - Other legitimate software that compiles binaries
    - Software development and installation
    - Script kiddies
level: medium
---

Detects suspicious binary compilation based on the 'pdb' and 'pdbstr' command-line arguments.

Input arguments to pdbstr can be used to set the symbol storage for a DLL (e.g. ".c" for a C file). This could allow for binary compilations for malicious purposes.

This rule detects only one of the following conditions:
- A parent process of a suspicious binary compilation spawns pdbstr
- A suspicious binary compilation spawns pdbstr

Additional checks are needed to determine if the compiled binary is malicious or not.

### Rule Definition

```yaml
id: 156c49b8-b6c1-42b9-9d1e-070d61642b7b
status: test
description: Detects suspicious binary compilation based on the 'pdb' and 'pdbstr' command-line arguments.
references:
    - https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/scientific-research/220160632126
author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)
date: 2021-11-26
modified: 2023-02-05
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.t1564.001
    - attack.s0105
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - pdbstr.exe
            - 'pdbstr'
            - 'c'
        CommandLine|contains|any:
            - 'compile'
            - 'pdb'
    condition: all of selection
falsepositives:
    - Legitimate developers
    - Other legitimate software that compiles binaries
    - Software development and installation
    - Script kiddies
level: medium
```

### Rules

```yaml
rules:
    - id: PECompilationCommandLine
      type: command
      # TODO add support for the pdbstr/pdb combination to the "parse" helper function
      # https://github.com/SigmaHQ/sigma/issues/3593
      status: test
      description: Detects suspicious binary compilation based on the 'pdb' and 'pdbstr' command-line arguments.
      reference:
        - https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/scientific-research/220160632126
      # TODO add support

input: "\taskmgr.exe"
id: ae1f7347-7728-4a8a-b027-c4f606b65818
status: test
description: |
    Detects the execution of taskmgr.exe.
    This can be used as a persistence mechanism by spawning taskmgr with the /f flag to show the desktop and launch the taskmgr.exe program.
    This has been observed used by some threat actors.
references:
    - https://thedfirreport.com/2023/10/15/stonesoup/
    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210418231620/https://twitter.com/Gam3r_Sp33d/status/1450958973663857927
    - https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/8d22754f68a238f7b1e160f817c42240dd342f35a96c7b8d6a4328a42005476
author: Beyu Denis, oscd.community
date: 2023-06-22
modified: 2024-02-02
tags:
    - attack.persistence
    - attack.t1033
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains: '\taskmgr.exe'
        Image|endswith: '\taskmgr.exe'
    # If the process isn't on the system (for example, it's a sandboxed process), then we don' 
    # want to consider it a legitimate process.
    # This is the same logic that's used by Windows defender.
    # Source: https://twitter.com/Gam3r_Sp33d/status/1450958973663857927
    # Relevant GitHub issue: https://github.com/SigmaHQ/sigtool/issues/203
    exclusion:
        ParentImage: '*\Winlogon.exe'
    condition: selection and not exclusion
falsepositives:
    - Legitimate applications using taskmgr.exe
level: medium

```

recommendation:
    - To detect a local DLL-based infection based on the run key (i.e. an installed application) or runonce (i.e. a startup group) registry keys.
    - Detect only when the parent image is "rundll32.exe".
    - Avoid using a signature-based detection rule with high confidence because of false positives
      (especially when the "OriginalFileName" and "FileName" values of the registry key are not set)
      or because of missed false negatives.
      Please note that an untrusted (local) DLL file can be loaded into a trusted process (e.  g. explorer.exe) via this
      command line.
      In this case, the process that loads the DLL into the trusted process will be identified in the process details of the
      parent process.
    - The "OriginalFileName" and "FileName" values of the registry key can be used to narrow down the search to specific DLL files.
      Please note that the "OriginalFileName" value is not set by default on the "UninstallString" registry key for applications.
      On the other hand, the "FileName" value is always set.
    - Select only when the registry key where the DLL

output_expected:
title: New DLL Registered Via Odbcconf.EXE
id: 9f0a8bf3-a65b-440a-8c1e-5cb1547c8e70
related:
    - id: ba4cfc11-d0fa-4d94-bf20-7c332c412e76
      type: similar
status: test
description: Detects execution of "odbcconf" with "REGSVR" in order to register a new DLL (equivalent to running regsvr32). Attackers abuse this to install and run malicious DLLs.
references:
    - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/odbc/odbcconf-exe?view=sql-server-ver16
    - https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/Binaries/Odbcconf/
    - https://redcanary.com/blog/raspberry-robin/
    - https://web.archive.org/web/20191023232753/https://twitter.com/Hexacorn/status/1187143326673330176
    - https://www.hexacorn.com/blog/2020/08/23/odbcconf-lolbin-trifecta/
    - https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/17/h/backdoor-carrying-emails-set-sights-on-russian-speaking-businesses.html
author: Kirill Kiryanov, Beyu Denis, Daniil Yugoslavskiy, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
date: 2023-05-22
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.t1218.008
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection_img:
        - Image|endswith: '\odbcconf.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'odbcconf.exe'
    selection_cli:
        # Note: The "/A" flag is not required to call a specific action
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - 'REGSVR '
            - '.dll'
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:
    - Legitimate DLLs being registered via "odbcconf" will generate false positives. Investigate the path of the DLL and its content to determine if the action is authorized.
level: medium
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\odbcconf.exe \"odbcco\"nf.exe REGSVR .dll

### Response:
@load rlutil run

input: Input = @load rlutil run
rlutil: Rlutil = rlutil run -r.regsvr
run: Run = rlutil run -r.dll

output_expected:
title: Cscript/Wscript Potentially Suspicious Child Process
id: b6676963-0353-4f88-90f5-36c20d443c6a
status: test
description: |
    Detects potentially suspicious child processes of Wscript/Cscript. These include processes such as rundll32 with uncommon exports or PowerShell spawning rundll32 or regsvr32.
    Malware such as Pikabot and Qakbot were seen using similar techniques as well as many others.
references:
    - Internal Research
    - https://github.com/pr0xylife/Pikabot/blob/fc58126127adf0f65e78f4eec59675523f48f086/Pikabot_30.10.2023.txt
    - https://github.com/pr0xylife/Pikabot/blob/fc58126127adf0f65e78f4eec59675523f48f086/Pikabot_22.12.2023.txt
author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems), Alejandro Houspanossian ('@lekz86')
date: 2023-05-15
modified: 2024-01-02
tags:
    - attack.execution
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection_parent:
        ParentImage|endswith:
            - '\wscript.exe'
            - '\cscript.exe'
    selection_cli_script_main:
        Image|endswith:
            - '\cmd.exe'
            - '\powershell.exe'
            - '\pwsh.exe'
    # Note: Add other combinations that are suspicious
    selection_cli_script_option_mshta:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - 'mshta'
            - 'http'
    selection_cli_script_option_other:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'rundll32'
            - 'regsvr32'
            - 'msiexec'
    selection_cli_standalone:
        Image|endswith: '\rundll32.exe'
    filter_main_rundll32_known_exports:
        Image|endswith: '\rundll32.exe'
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'UpdatePerUserSystemParameters'
            - 'PrintUIEntry'
            - 'ClearMyTracksByProcess'
    condition: selection_parent and ( selection_cli_standalone or (selection_cli_script_main and 1 of selection_cli_script_option_*) ) and not 1 of filter_main_*
falsepositives:
    - Some false positives might occur with admin or third party software scripts. Investigate and apply additional filters accordingly.
level: medium
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\wscript \cscript \cmd \powershell \pwsh mshta http rundll32 regsvr32 msiexec \rundll32 \rundll32 UpdatePerUserSystemParameters PrintUIEntry ClearMyTracksByProcess

### Response:
Input: \wscript \cscript \cmd \powershell \pwsh mshta http rundll32 regsvr32 msiexec \rundll32 \rundll32 UpdatePerUserSystemParameters PrintUIEntry ClearMyTracksByProcess

### powershell
```
Get-ChildItem -Path HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services -Recurse -Filter "Start" -Name -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | ForEach-Object {
    $Parent = Split-Path $_\Parent -Parent
    $Name = Split-Path $_ -Leaf
    $Value = Get-ItemProperty -Path $_ -Name Start
    if ($Value.Start -eq 4) {
        New-Object psobject -Property @{
            Parent   = $Parent
            Name     = $Name
            Start    = $Value.Start
            CommandLine = (Get-ItemProperty -Path $Parent -Name CommandLine).CommandLine
        }
    }
} | Where-Object {$_.Start -eq 4}

```


### es-qs
```
winlog.event_data.ParentImage: '*\powershell.exe'
winlog.event_data.CommandLine.keyword: 'Set-Service -StartupType Disabled'
```

title: Reconnaissance
id: 9175d36f-8f79-496b-8647-4a0728350103
status: test
description: |
    Detects a series of commands associated with the discovery of information within an Active Directory environment.
    Active Directory is the central authentication service in a Windows domain.
    It stores users, computers, printers and other network resources as objects.
    Active Directory objects can be queried using a command line utility called "dsquery".
    This utility is used for the discovery of information within the Active Directory environment.
    In some cases, attackers may abuse this utility to gain further insights on the target Active Directory environment.
references:
    - https://www.mandiant.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Mandiant-Crossfit-Covid-Report-public.pdf
    - https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-22/archives/2200080-Reconstructing-The-Incident-On-Vault7-DarkSide-Telecom-Credential-Disclosure-Slides.pdf
    - https://app.any.run/tasks/4553644e-56e2-4b79-8274-df5e14373f2b/
    - https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/OtherMisc/Dsquery/
author: Beyu Denis, TPCOIN-CC
date: 2023-06-19
modified: 2024-12-27
tags:
    - attack.discovery
    - attack.t1587
    - attack.t1087
    - attack.credential-access
    - attack.t1003.003
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - dsquery.exe
            - trustedDomain
    condition: selection
falsepositives:
    - Unused / unknown
level: medium

---

### General Description:

A popular Active Directory tool that is part of the Microsoft operating system.

"dsquery.exe" can be used to enumerate Active Directory (AD) objects by specifying their LDAP distinguished names.
This utility is used by malware authors for their reconnaissance phase.
Active Directory is the central authentication service in a Windows domain.
It stores users, computers, printers and other network resources as objects.

Adversaries can abuse "dsquery" to gain further insights into the target Active Directory environment.
This includes discovering the domain controllers, trusted domains, domain objects (OU), domain group policy (GPO) settings, and users, computers, printers and other objects.

    selection_img:
        - Image|endswith: '\rundll32.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'RUNDLL32.EXE'
        - CommandLine|contains: 'rundll32'
    selection_cli:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - '#+'
            - '#-'
            # ordinal can be represented by adding any number of zeros in front ordinal number, for e.g. 000000024
            - '#0'
            # ordinal is 16 bit ordinal, so if you make the number large enough (don't fit in 16 bit space), then it normally wraps around.
            # for e.g ordinal 24 can be also represented by 65560 (65536+24)
            - '#655'
            - '#656'
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:
    - Unknown
level: medium
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\rundll32.exe RUNDLL32.EXE rundll32 #+ #- #0 #655 #656

### Response:
@load run_pe_code
Input: \rundll32.exe
template: file_img_b_64u_r_p
id: 1644973c-b29b-4dda-abf7-e3f0761a818d
status: test
description: Detects rundll32 with the "1644973c-b29b-4dda-abf7-e3f0761a818d" template
references:
    - https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/OtherMsbinaries/Rundll32/
    - https://twitter.com/Lotusbl33d/status/1487530857969772032
    - https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/10/bypassing-defender-smartscreen.html
author: Beyu Denis,  @Lotusbl33d
date: 2022-11-08
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.execution
    - attack.s0111
    - attack.t1566.  #  # #  #   # #  #
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - 'RUNDLL32'
            - '#'
            - '+''
            - '0'
            - '655'
            - '656'
    # We only check for the existence of the following registry keys because when the program
    # is registered with the COM API as it should be in production, these values will be set.
    # The presence of these values indicates that the program is in the right place.
    # We don't check for the existence of specific values since these values vary by program.
    # The names of the values that are checked are the same for all programs, so we only need
    # to check for the presence of the keys.
    all_reg_values_present:
        # For rundll32
        - HKCU:
            Software\Classes\Applications\rundll32
            Startup
        - HKLM:
            Software\Classes\Applications\rundll32
            Startup
        # For the target executable
        - HKCU:
            Software\Classes\CLSID\rundll32
            InProcHandler
            LocalServer32
            ProgId
            ThreadingModel
            VersionIndependentProgId
        - HKLM:
            Software\Classes\CLSID\rundll32
            InProcHandler
            LocalServer32
            ProgId
            ThreadingModel
            VersionIndependentProgId
    all_dll_files_exist:
        any_of:
            # For rundll32
            - HKCU:
                Software\Classes\Applications\rundll3 2
                Startup
            - HKLM:
                Software\Classes\Applications\rundll32
                Startup
            # For the target executable
            - HKCU:
                Software\Classes\CLSID\rundll32
                InProcHandler
                LocalServer32
                ProgId
                ThreadingModel
                VersionIndependentProgId
            - HKLM:
                Software\Classes\CLSID\rundll32
                InProcHandler
                LocalServer32
                ProgId
                ThreadingModel
                VersionIndependentProgId
    # Detects if the program is registered in the COM API
    reg_key_exists:
        all_of:
            - HKCU:
                Software\Classes\CLSID\rundll32
                InProcHandler
                LocalServer32
                ProgId
                ThreadingModel
                VersionIndependentProgId
            - HKLM:
                Software\Classes\CLSID\rundll32
                InProcHandler
                LocalServer32
                ProgId
                ThreadingModel
                VersionIndependentProgId

description: |
  Detects execution of "SharpLDAPmonitor.exe", a.NET assembly capable of monitoring changes in LDAP servers.
  Adversaries may use this tool to collect and monitor changes in LDAP servers in order to discover and acquire information.
  An adversary may also abuse this tool to perform credential dumping or impersonation using the "searchuser" function.

output_expected:
title: Use Of The SFTP.EXE Binary As A LOLBIN
id: a85ffc3a-e8fd-4040-93bf-78aff284d801
status: test
description: Detects the usage of the "sftp.exe" binary as a LOLBIN by abusing the "-D" flag
references:
    - https://github.com/LOLBAS-Project/LOLBAS/pull/264
author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
date: 2022-11-10
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.execution
    - attack.t1218
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        Image|endswith: '\sftp.exe' # The "sftp.exe" located in the OpenSSH directory has no OriginalFileName :(
        CommandLine|contains:
            # Since "-D" is a valid flag for other usage we assume the user is going to enter a path
            # Either a full one like "C:\Windows\System32\calc.exe" or a relative one "..\..\..\Windows\System32\calc.exe"
            # In my testing you can't execute direct binaries by their name via this method (if you found a way please update the rule)
            - ' -D ..'
            - ' -D C:\'
    condition: selection
falsepositives:
    - Unknown
level: medium
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\sftp.exe -D .. -D \"C\"\":\"\"\\"

---

Detects usage of sftp.exe to download a file from a given path.

When a process spawns with sftp.exe as the parent, if the binary was invoked with a "D" flag, followed by a path and the double backslash symbol (\"C\"\:...) then the binary will download the given file.

This can be used to retrieve files from a remote location.

### Sigma rule

Input: \sftp.exe -D.. -D \"C\"":\"\"\\"

- Atomic Test #1 - Takeown.exe - Admin Rights
Take ownership of a file. This will likely trigger a security audit and a few notifications to the user.

Replace the file permissions and take ownership of a file.
This will likely trigger a security audit and a few notifications to the user.

    takeown /f c:\temp\mal_file.doc /r /d
    takeown /f c:\temp\mal_file.doc /r /d


- Atomic Test #3 - Takeown - Replace Owner
Replace the file owner and take ownership of a file.
This will likely trigger a security audit and a few notifications to the user.

    takeown /f c:\temp\mal_file.doc /r /d

    $newacl | ForEach-Object { $_.IsInherited = $false }

    $newacl | ForEach-Object { $_.ObjectType = '*' }
    $newacl | ForEach-Object { $_.InheritedObjectType = '*' }

    $newacl | ForEach-Object { $_.Trustee = 'NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM' }

### Instruction: Write Sigma rule to detect payload: ### Input: Cmd CONHOST 7z WinRAR wevtutil net net1 netsh InstallUtil \cmd \conhost \7z \WinRAR \wevtutil \net \net1 \netsh \InstallUtil ### Response: input: Cmd CONHOST 7z WinRAR wevtutil net net1 netsh InstallUtil output: condition: row2_contains('Cmd', 'CONHOST', '7z', 'WinRAR', 'wevtutil', 'net', 'net1', 'netsh', 'InstallUtil') description: Detects suspicious process as child of win32 parent id: f1af2110-40d1-41d6-af7c-1a1154208269 status: test tags: - attack.execution - attack.t1059 - attack.s0055 - attack.t1218 - attack.t1219 - car.2016-04-002 - stolabs.comtrend - stolabs.hpcna - stolabs.snort - stolabs.supply_chain_bypass - stolabs.uprobe - stolabs.zeus related: - id: 7c10649a-99b3-4d5d-81a5-0e21f75d4f82 type: similar - id: ef0e3508-2f7c-4692-a495-7363c7929275 type: obsolete - id: 2849a4bf-b0a9-42f8-b114-d75c63f47b74 type: mitigation author: Timur Yunusov (Nextron Systems) date: 2020-05-01 modifier: Sigma rule template severity: medium references: - https://blog.netspi.com/14-days-in-the-life-of-a-powershell-parent/ - https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2018/08/a-closer-look-at-powershell-hijackings-in-advanced-persistent-threat-apt.html - https://blog.symantec.com/hunting-for-powersehll-hijacking - https://eqllib.readthedocs.io/en/latest/analytics/72d24220-a446-11eb-95c2-a5e0f0175647.html - https://www module.net/blog/156255-PowerShell-Parent-Injection-Analytics-Script - https://gist.github.com/bohops/637b655c3422c418a47d2835533544f4 - https://github.com/bohops/PSIStorm description: | Detects process spawned as children of "win32" PE binary as commonly abused by Windows malware. Might be used by various attackers as a way to execute code or bypass Antivirus/EDR.

PE files used for process creation can be signed and notarized with Authenticode which is the main indicator of the legitimacy of a file. This makes the possibility of using "unnotarized" or unsigned binary as a legitimate PE to spawn the process very slim.

"Cmd" PE can also be used for the same purpose and provides the most generic indicator of legitimacy which makes the possibility of using it very high.

"InstallUtil" is also very high on the list of potential suspects. It is a.Net based binary that allows developers to install and uninstall.Net framework managed assemblies (or any other assembly for that matter).

"Conhost" is a terminal emulator and can be used by the malware in order to hide their activities.

# Windows Service Discovery

Adversaries may enumerate information about services on the system, including things like service name, display name, and start mode (for example, manual, automatic, disabled, etc). This can help discovery adversary activity, from defensive configuration monitoring, to locating and altering system settings.

### Possible Impact
Unknown.

### Possible Countermeasures
Unknown.

### Potential Tools

- WMIC
- wmic.exe
- powershell (Get-Service)
- pwsh (Get-Service)
- PowerShell Empire (Get-Service function)
- p sh (Get-Service function)
- p s h (Get-Service function)

### Detection Blind/False Positives

  -  "Displayname" of the Service may be misspelled.

### How to Implement

Select from "Potential Tools" section based on  from from package name, if you find it is available on the host.
  'wmic.exe' is required.
  - use "wmic.exe service get name,displayname,--pathname,startmode" command to get the information.
  -  'wmic.exe' may not be installed on the host, thus, this specific use case won't work as expected.
  -  "Displayname" of the Service may be misspelled.
  -  use "--pathname" to get more information about the service.

### Specifications

- Microsoft Security Advisory (Severity: Medium)
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 2016-004
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 2016-015
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 2016-040
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 2 // 12/03/2015
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 3 // 04/04/2016
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 4 // 13/04/2016
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 5 // 18/04/2016
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 6 // 28/04/2016
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 7 // 08/05/2016
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 8 // 19/05/2016
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 9 // 10/06/2016
    - Microsoft Security Advisory 10 // 11/06/201

id: 9d5a1274-922a-49d0-87f3-8c653483b909
related:
    - id: d85ecdd7-b855-4e6e-af59-d9c78b5b861e
      type: derived
status: test
description: |
    Detects the use of the WMI command-line (WMIC) utility to identify and display various system information,
    including OS, CPU, GPU, and disk drive names; memory capacity; display resolution; and baseboard, BIOS,
    and GPU driver products/versions.
    Some of these commands were used by Aurora Stealer in late 2022/early 2023.
references:
    - https://github.com/redcanaryco/atomic-red-team/blob/a2ccd19c37d0278b4ffa8583add3cf52060a5418/atomics/T1082/T1082.md#atomic-test-25---system-information-discovery-with-wmic
    - https://nwgat.ninja/getting-system-information-with-wmic-on-windows/
    - https://blog.sekoia.io/aurora-a-rising-stealer-flying-under-the-radar
    - https://blog.cyble.com/2023/01/18/aurora-a-stealer-using-shapeshifting-tactics/
    - https://app.any.run/tasks/a6aa0057-82ec-451f-8f99-55650ca537da/
    - https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/d6f6bc10ae0e634ed4301d584f61418cee18e5d58ad9af72f8aa552dc4aaeca3/behavior
author: TropChaud
date: 2023-01-26
modified: 2023-12-19
tags:
    - attack.discovery
    - attack.t1082
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection_wmic:
        - Description: 'WMI Commandline Utility'
        - OriginalFileName: 'wmic.exe'
        - Image|endswith: '\WMIC.exe'
    selection_commands:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'LOGICALDISK get Name,Size,FreeSpace'
            - 'os get Caption,OSArchitecture,Version'
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:
    - Unknown
level: medium
output_model:

### powershell
    
```
Get-WinEvent -LogName Security -FilterXPath /Event/System/EventID/text()=4688  # event id for the creation of a symbolic link
| where TimeCreated > "2020-03-01"
| where EventID == 4688
| where commandline contains'mklink HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy'
| select TimeCreated, @Timestamp, Computer, User, CommandLine
| table Computer, User, CommandLine

```


### es-qs
    
```
winlog.event_data.CommandLine.keyword:*mklink* *HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy*
winlog.event_data.EventID:"4688"

```


### xpack-watcher
    
```
watcher winlog --dsn 'LDAP://CN=EvtxDB,CN=System,DC=XC,DC=LAB'  --log-template -t security -i commandline --attribute '4688' --data-type "keyword" --query 'winlog.event_data.CommandLine.keyword:*mklink* *HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy*'  // '1124'  // '3740'
watcher winlog --dsn 'LDAP://CN=EvtxDB,CN=System,DC=XC,DC=LAB'  --log-template -t security -i eventid --attribute '4688' --data-type "keyword" --query 'winlog.event_data.EventID:"4688"'  // '1124'  // '3740'

```


### splunk
    
```
(winlog_event_id:"4688"  -Commandline="*mklink* *HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy*")
| table Computer, User, CommandLine
| rename Computer as dest
| rename User as user
| rename CommandLine as _raw
```


### logpoint
    
```
data/winlog_security 
| search "CommandLine.keyword:*mklink* *HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy*" 
| filter EventID=4688 
| fields -CommandLine -event_id
| rename Computer as dest
| rename User as user
| rename OriginalFileName as _raw
```


### grep
    
```
grep --huge -P 'winlog_event_id:"4688"' /var/log/winlogbeat/security* | grep -P 'Commandline.keyword:*mklink* *HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy*'
```

status: test
description: |
    Detects execution of "certmgr" with the "add" flag in order to install a new certificate on the system.
    Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers.
references:
    - https://github.com/redcanaryco/atomic-red-team/blob/f339e7da7d05f6057fdfcdd3742bfcf365fee2a9/atomics/T1553.004/T1553.004.md

date: 2023-03-05

    - attack.t1553.004
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    # Example: CertMgr.exe /add CertificateFileName.cer /s /r localMachine root /all
    selection_img:
        - Image|endswith: '\CertMgr.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'CERTMGT.EXE'
    selection_cli:
        CommandLine|contains|all:

            - 'root'
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:

level: medium

    Detects usage of the CertMgr.exe utility for adding trusted CA certificates.

### description
Detects the execution of the "chcp.com" application via cmd.exe in order to change the active code page

### author
Nextron Systems, Nasreddine Bencherchali

### powerdbg flags

    ignorecase: true
    ignoreaccent: true

### related techniques

* https://gist.github.com/msekliba/077109f236241c4e9268815915704d49

### atomic test

Input:
Combines several techniques in order to change the active code page via cmd.exe. In particular it executes chcp.com with the following command to get the current codepage, store the value as a variable and use it later to restore the original value.
Note that this technique requires the execution of the Cobalt Strike from within a remote session and as such it is highly unlikely to succeed unless the attacker is able to run the Cobalt Strike locally or inside a process within the session.

Atomic Test 1 - Locale Change Via Command Prompt (cmd.exe)
Command: \cmd.exe -c -r -k \"\chcp.com\" 1 0 932 5124
Input:
OriginalFileName: 'cmd.exe'  # the name of the parent process
Image|endswith: '\chcp.com'  # the name of the file executed
selection: 
    OriginalFileName: 'cmd.ee'  # the name of the parent process
    Image|endswith: '\chcp.com'  # the name of the file executed
condition: selection

MATCH (A: process_creation)<-[:parent_process]-(B: process_creation)

RETURN A.process_id, A.OriginalFileName, B.OriginalFileName, B.CommandLine,

```

status: stable
description: |
  Detects suspicious parameters of fsutil (deleting USN journal, configuring it with small size, etc).

references:
    - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/fsutil-usn
    - https://github.com/redcanaryco/atomic-red-team/blob/f339e7da7d05f6057fdfcdd3742bfcf365fee2a9/atomics/T1070/T1070.md

logsource:

    product: windows
detection:
    selection_img:
        - Image|endswith: '\fsutil.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'fsutil.exe'
    selection_cli:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'deletejournal'        # usn deletejournal ==> generally ransomware or attacker
            - 'createjournal'        # usn createjournal ==> can modify config to set it to a tiny size
            - 'setZeroData'          # file setZeroData  ==> empties a file with zeroes
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:

level: high
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\fsutil.exe fsutil.exe "d""e""l""e""t""e""j""o""u""r""n""a""l" createjournal setZeroData

### Response:
```
```

### Detection:
Potential execution of fsutil.exe, looking for the specific command-line arguments that are used to create/del journal and setZeroData.

### Sourcetypes:
- fs:access - Logs file system events
- image - Logs events related to images being loaded
- security:auditd_daemon - Logs events from auditd daemon
- security:windows_events - Logs events from windows event log
- system:device - Logs system device information
- system:network - Logs system network information
- system:powershell - Logs system powershell events

### Attribution:
@bohops, @carlosk, @harrneyscott

### References:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/fsutil-fsfree-nfsexports

https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/Binaries/Fsutil/

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-2000-server/cc732960%28v=ws.10%29

### Author:

Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center, @carlosk

### Date:

2022-07-26

### Status:

Verified

### Description:
Detects the execution of the "fsutil" command line with the parameters createjournal and setZeroData,
which is used to create and manage journals in an NTFS file system.
This is used to hide the files that are created on the disk by the attacker or other adversary.
Adversaries often use this functionality to hide files.
In rare cases, it can also be used to bypass defender detection mechanisms.

    Detects usage of winget to install applications via manifest file. Adversaries can abuse winget to download payloads remotely and execute them.
    The manifest option enables you to install an application by passing in a YAML file directly to the client.
    Winget can be used to download and install exe, msi or msix files later.
references:
    - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/package-manager/winget/install#local-install

title: Allow Service Access Using Security Descriptor Tampering Via Sc.EXE
id: 6c8fbee5-dee8-49bc-851d-c3142d02aa47
related:
    - id: a537cfc3-4297-4789-92b5-345bfd845ad0 # Generic SD tampering
      type: similar
status: test
description: Detects suspicious DACL modifications to allow access to a service from a suspicious trustee. This can be used to override access restrictions set by previous ACLs.
references:
    - https://twitter.com/0gtweet/status/1628720819537936386
    - https://itconnect.uw.edu/tools-services-support/it-systems-infrastructure/msinf/other-help/understanding-sddl-syntax/
    - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/secauthz/sid-strings
author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
date: 2023-02-28
tags:
    - attack.persistence
    - attack.t1543.003
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection_sc:
        - Image|endswith: '\sc.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'sc.exe'
    selection_sdset:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - 'sdset'
            - 'A;' # Allow Access
    selection_trustee:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - ';IU' # Interactively logged-on user
            - ';SU' # Service logon user
            - ';BA' # Built-in administrators
            - ';SY' # Local system
            - ';WD' # Everyone
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:
    - Unknown
level: high
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\sc.exe sc.exe sdset A; ;IU ;SU \";BA\" ;SY ;WD

### Response:
id: 5060b925-671f-4092-bfe8-9150a4726b89
status: test
description: Detects usage of the sc.exe tool to allow anonymous logons
references:
    - https://thedfirreport.com/2022/07/09/the-bhagat-incident/
    - https://www.harmjoest-rue.nl/pwning-a-wifi-lock-bhagat-battery-converter/
author: Timur Zinovyev, 3k1t, harmjoest
date: 2022-07-09
modified: 2022-08-10
tags:
    - attack.persistence
    - attack.t1098
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - sc.exe
            -'sc.exe'
            - sdset
            - A
            - IA
            - DA
            - PA
            - SBA
            - SA
            - WD
        Ancestors|contains:
            - sc.exe
    condition: all of (selection, ancestors)
falsepositives:
    - In rare cases, an application might require to perform a task related to changing the security descriptor for the service in the process of its normal operation.
level: critical
timeline_threshold: 0
modularity: complete
---

Attackers might abuse "sc.exe" tool to modify the security descriptor (SD) of a service.

The security descriptor (SD) contains the security information for the object, such as user rights and access control lists (ACLs).

An attacker might use this technique to make a service or process run in an elevated context by granting "SeServiceLogonRight" and "SeDenyServiceLogonRight" to the service logon account.

The SD can also be used to remove or restrict the built-in "SeInteractiveLogonRight" access right.

Adversaries might use this technique in order to bypass UAC and run a legitimate process in the context of the administrator.

### Unit Tests

#### Test Case 1:
Disable the interactive logon access rights for a service via "sc.exe"

Input: \sc.exe sdset A; ;IU; ;SU; \";BA\" ;SY; ;WD BINARYENCRYPTIONDATA NTDS-SYNC NTDSQUOTA NTDSSETUP WINRM-REMOTE-NDR GLOBAL-MANAGER
id: 30397b59-83b8-4b5a-9f66-11d293657f65
status: test
description: |
    Adversaries may modify service permissions to allow it to logon with the Anonymous account,
    which can allow execution of the service as SYSTEM.  An anonymous logon occurs when a service
    logon account has been granted the Anonymous logon right.  This can occur when a service is created
    or modified with the "Sc.exe" utility.  In order for this to happen, a service must be created
    with the flag "Untrusted" in order to allow anonymous access.
    Threat actor TroyKelley has used this technique on several occasions, such as when they abused the
    "Microsoft Online Services Sign-In Assistant" in July 2016 (Cobalt Group) in order to logon to
    an interactive desktop.  An attacker would use a copy of the utility that was signed by a trusted
    developer and had it on a USB stick.
references:
    - https://github.com/mandiant/ThreatHunter-Playbook/blob/9fdd877d8b45e06c68754a110c9b67d6d72e99bb/docs/courses/windows/2.1-T1136.1-S011/1.3-Adversary-Employed-Sc-E-Sc

title: Command-Line Anomaly
id: 142d19e3-384d-4d0d-9f47-49b4b2417b91
status: test
description: |
    Executes a binary that is not present in the filesystem using a different binary in order to "spoof" the path.
    This may be indicative of a possible abuse, such as trying to use CDB to list files from another drive or execute
    an "image" file that is not actually a binary file.
    It could also be used for other abuses like hiding process, changing working directory or executing a file on another drive
references:
    - https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/11/leaked-malware-impersonates-adobe-flash-player.html
author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
date: 2021-11-12
modified: 2022-11-14
tags:
    - attack.command-and-control
    - attack.t1059.005
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        ParentImage|endswith: '\cdb.exe'
        Image|endswith: '\'.exe'
    filter:
        OriginalFileName|!endswith: '.exe'
    condition: selection and not filter
falsepositives:
    - Unknown
level: medium
recommendation:
    - Requires custom analysis based on "OriginalFileName" and "CommandLine" to confirm this is a genuine case of command-line anomaly.
    - If the execution of "CDB" is not seen in the exported Sysmon data, then this may indicate an abuse of the "CDB" tool and should be investigated further.
    - Sensitive data or binaries could also be executed by using a different binary as a "spoof" path.
    - This is a "heavy" type of detection which will lead to a lot of false positives so the best way to reduce the noise is to do a custom analysis of the "CommandLine" field and the "OriginalFileName" field and verify this is a genuine case of "command-line anomaly"
    - The "CDB" tool may be abused to list files on other drives and execute files that are not actually binaries.
    - Also, this can be used to hide process and execute a file that is on another drive.
    - The "CommandLine" and the "OriginalFileName" field may contain valuable information that can help with the analysis.
    - Anomalies are when a program executes an executable that is not present in the filesystem.
    - The execution of the "CDB" is used as a "spoof" to show a different path than the actual program path
    - Anomalies are when a program executes an executable that is not present in the filesystem
    - The execution of the "Cdb" is used as a "spoof" to show a different path than the actual program path
    - This technique can be abused in order to list files on other drives or execute a file that is not actually a binary file.
    - Anomalies are when a program executes an executable that is not present in the filesystem
    - This technique can be abused to hide process and execute a file that is on another drive.
    - This technique can also be abused to "spoof" a path in order to show a different path than the actual program path
    - The "Cdb" tool is a debugger for Windows.
    - This means that "CDB" can be abused to execute "image" files that are not actually binaries, which is used by other "ransomware" families such as NotPetya and WannaCry.
    - Also, this tool can be used to list files on other drives and execute binaries that are not actually binaries.
    - This technique can be used to hide processes and execute files that are on another drive.
    - This technique can also be used to "spoof" a path in order to show a different path than the actual program path

    - ImageFileNaem - file name with path

```
sed -n's/.*UserInitMprLogonScript: \(.*\)\".*/\1/p' /proc/1/environ

### awk

```
awk -F '=' '/\bUserInitMprLogonScript\b/' /proc/1/environ
```

### tail

tail /proc/1/environ
```

    - https://www.hybrid-analysis.com/sample/f16c729aad5c74f19784a24257236a8bbe27f7cdc4a89806031ec7f1bebbd475?environmentId=100
author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Jonhnathan Ribeiro, oscd.community

            - 'http' # captures both http and https
            - '://'

fields:
    - CommandLine
    - ParentCommandLine
falsepositives:
    - High

Input: \cmd.exe http :// %AppData%
id: 20d570d1-d0d6-4438-967d-82033b51703f
status: test
description: |
    Detects a process command line that uses "http" in the beginning of it, which means that the process is accessing the internet
references:
    - https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/03/ransomware-with-wannacry-variants.html
    - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/security/compass/malware-family-168554
author: Tal Remez, C.Y.L.
date: 2022-03-28
modified: 2022-04-02
tags:
    - attack.command-and-control
    - attack.t1036
    - attack.discovery
    - attack.s0017
    - car.2016-03-002
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'http:'
    condition: selection
falsepositives:
    - Unlikely
level: medium
---

### Description

In March 2022, Talos released a blog about the "USBHack" malware.
The malware is a derivative of the famous WannaCry ransomware and the "USBHack" family of malware.

According to the Talos researcher, the malware was "diligent" in collecting bank information and other financial data.
In this case, the data was stored on USB devices.

Attackers may collect financial data by monitoring a USB device for write events.
In order to execute their collection and harvesting processes, the "USBHack" family of malware will access the Internet, such as for DNS resolution.

This detection rule looks for the "http" keyword in the beginning of the command line, which can be used to identify the presence of the Internet access for the target process.

### Recommended Secure Configurations

No specific recommended secure configurations for this detection rule.

### Sigma rule

Input: \cmd.exe http :// %AppData%
id: 20d570d1-d0d6-4438-967d-82033b51703f
status: test
description: |
    Detects a process command line that uses "http" in the beginning of it, which means that the process is accessing the internet.
    Adversaries use the Internet for a variety of tasks such as reconnaissance, remote access, and remote code execution.
    A common way for adversaries to access the Internet is by using command-line interfaces (CLIs) to communicate with online services such as HTTP-based services.
references:
    - https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/03/ransomware-with-wannacry-variants.html
    - https://learn.microsoft. /* Microsoft Documentation */
    author: Tal Remez, C.Y.L.
    date: 2022-03-28
    modified: 2022-04-02
    tags:
        - attack.command-and-control
        - attack.t1036
        - attack.discovery
        - attack.s0017
        - car.2016-03-002
    logsource:
        category: process_creation
        product: windows
    detection:
        selection:
            CommandLine|contains:
                - 'http:'
        condition: selection
    falsepositives:
        - Unlikely
    level: medium
    modifiers:
        # use 4 to include the 'http' part
        pattern_type: "longest_streak"
        negated: true
    type: heuristic
    related:
        - id: 20371a14-09a4-4703-8348

output_expected:
title: File Deletion Via Del
id: 379fa130-190e-4c3f-b7bc-6c8e834485f3
status: test
description: |
    Detects execution of the builtin "del"/"erase" commands in order to delete files.
    Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity.
    Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how.
    Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint.
references:
    - https://github.com/redcanaryco/atomic-red-team/blob/f339e7da7d05f6057fdfcdd3742bfcf365fee2a9/atomics/T1070.004/T1070.004.md
    - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/erase
author: frack113
date: 2022-01-15
modified: 2024-03-05
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.t1070.004
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection_img:
        - Image|endswith: '\cmd.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'Cmd.Exe'
    selection_del:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'del '
            - 'erase '
    selection_flags:
        CommandLine|contains|windash:
            - ' -f' # Force deleting of read-only files.
            - ' -s' # Delete specified files from all subdirectories.
            - ' -q' # Quiet mode, do not ask if ok to delete on global wildcard
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:
    - False positives levels will differ Depending on the environment. You can use a combination of ParentImage and other keywords from the CommandLine field to filter legitimate activity
level: low
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\cmd.exe Cmd.Exe del erase -f -s -q

### Response:
An adversary can use deleted files as a pivot point to launch additional executions.
Certain tools that adversaries might use during their operations could leave behind residual files that can be used as a pivot points for further attacks.
Adversaries can use deleted files as a pivot points for further operations.
For example, a Web Shell that is used by adversaries to execute commands could leave behind files (backup files) that can be used as a pivot point to launch additional executions.
These files include LNK files (shortcuts), EXEs, DLLs, or other files that could be used to launch a program.
One method adversaries may use is to delete files they no longer need and then leave a reference file on the compromised system as a reference for future use.
Given the frequency of adversaries deleting files, it is worth monitoring for deleted files and looking for any reference files that could be used for future operations.


### Detection:

These are just examples of common deleted files, but adversaries have been known to use other files as pivot points, such as.msi files, shortcut files, or other common files like log files.
Commonly deleted files can include.bat,.vbs,.ps1,.lnk, and.exe files.

The query looks for any time a process named "cmd.exe" deletes files with the commonly used flags for commonly deleted files:

  -f
  -s
  -q

Within 30 seconds of a deleted file by a cmd.exe process.

### Implementations:

The following are examples of detecting common deleted files by flags:

#### Sigma Rule

Input: \cmd.exe Cmd.Exe del erase -f -s -q within 30s
id: c59d84a3-85d7-46a4-bf2e-662b6689f3af
status: test
description: |
  Detects command line arguments commonly used when deleting files.
  Adversaries can leave behind deleted files for later use when they delete them.
  This can be leveraged to find any files that were left behind on the compromised system for later use.
references:
    - https://web.archive.org/web/20171117113849/http://www.yuvi.de/publications/Yuvi_DCU2013_PowerShellPersistenceBypass.pdf
    - https://www.eisbahn-ip.eu/hacking-in-the-corporate-network/
    - https://app.any.run/tasks/70734c41-5e78-4827-9a3f-913171417c83
author: Scott Thomas, Dylan Jayne, NSA, Adrian Herrera, SIGSAB, Rapid7, SCYTHE, Sigma, FPT.International, Red Canary, DerpSci
date: 2023-01-05
modified: 2024-05-29
tags:
    - attack.execution
    - attack.discovery
    - attack.persistence
    - attack.t1564
logsource:

    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - 'del'
            - 'erase'
            - 'f'
            -'s'
            - 'q'
    filter1:
        ParentCommandLine|contains|any:
            - 'cmd.exe'
            - 'CMD.EXE'
    filter2:
        OriginalFileName|endswith:
            - 'exe'
            - 'bat'
            - 'vbs'
            - 'ps1'
            - 'lnk'
            - 'dll'
            - 'com'
            -'scr'
    condition: all of selection filter1 filter2
falsepositives:
    - Uncommon or unknown applications may delete files with the commonly used flags and "del"
    - Certain tools that adversaries might use during their operations could leave behind residual files that can be used as a pivot points for future attacks.
    - Likely legitimate use of "del" or "

title: Arbitrary File Download Via MSOHTMED.EXE
id: 459f2f98-397b-4a4a-9f47-6a5ec2f1c69d
status: test
description: Detects usage of "MSOHTMED" to download arbitrary files
references:
    - https://github.com/LOLBAS-Project/LOLBAS/pull/238/files
author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
date: 2022-08-19
modified: 2023-11-09
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.execution
    - attack.t1218
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection_img:
        - Image|endswith: '\MSOHTMED.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'MsoHtmEd.exe'
    selection_cli:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'ftp://'
            - 'http://'
            - 'https://'
    condition: all of selection_*
falsepositives:
    - Unknown
level: medium
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\MSOHTMED MsoHtmEd ftp:// http:// https://

### Response:
Analyze the request headers to determine if the request is to a known web server that would lead to the execution of the binary.
The binary can be executed using the.bat extension, as well as the binary itself if it is compiled as an executable binary.
A common technique used by threat actors is to pack the binary inside a DLL file and then pass it to the WebDAV server.

### Detection:
In order to detect the behavior mentioned above, the following checks are performed:
- The user agent field of the request contains the word "msotedge" which would indicate a request from Microsoft Edge WebView2
- The "Referer" header is empty or is the same as the request URL
- The "Content-Disposition" header is empty or is set to "inline"
- The extension of the request URL is one of the following:
    - bat
    - pdb
    - dll
    - so
    - exe

### Possible Noise:
False positives could be raised if a request with a suspicious extension is made to a known web server such as a webDAV server.
This can be mitigated by ensuring that the parent directories of the file being downloaded are owned by a user that belongs to the well-known software owner SID (S-1-15-32-544).
The detection mechanism is also subject to a potential noise by looking for "msotedge" in the user agent field, which could lead to false positives if a suspicious request is made by Microsoft Edge or a browser running inside the Microsoft Edge WebView2.

### Data Model:

| Field | Type | Description | Example |
| ----- | ---- | ----------- | ------- |
| FileName | String | Name of the downloaded file | MsoHtmEd.dll |
| PEHash | String | PE hash of the downloaded file | 33636F796F69E168E06B402B0F168E0 |
| ParentDirectorySID | String | SID of the parent directory that owns the file | S-1-15-32-544 |
| URL | String | Full URL of the downloaded file | https://10.10.10.10/MsoHtmEd.dll |

### Reference:

    # If the parent process is not "dnx.exe", then we compare the "OriginalFileName" of the child and its parent processes. If they don't match, then we consider it suspicious.

    # If the parent process is "dnx.exe" then we compare the "CommandLine" of the child and its parent processes.
    # If they don't match, then we consider it suspicious.
    # We also compare the "Imprint" to filter out the processes that don'  #7758
    #. We check if the parent process is dnx.exe and compare the "Imprint" to filter out the processes that don't require any parameters.
    # The "Imprint" is used to determine whether a process is legitimate or not.
    # If the parent process is not "dnx.exe" then we compare the "CommandLine" to filter out the processes that don't require any parameters.
    # The "CommandLine" is used to determine whether a process is legitimate or not.
    # This is used to ensure that the child process that is started by "dnx.exe" isn't being started with any arguments.
    # We also compare the "Imprint" to filter out the processes that don't require any parameters.

    # If the parent process is "dnx.exe" then we compare the "CommandLine" to filter out the processes that don't require any parameters.

    # This is used to ensure that the child process that is started by "dnx.exe" isn't being started with any arguments.
    # We also compare the "Imprint" to filter out the processes that don't require any parameters.

    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        Image|endswith: '\rar.exe'
        CommandLine|contains: ' a '
    condition: selection

status: test
description: Detects the command line flags for the popular RAR compression tool, which may be abused by ransomware in order to encrypt files prior to delivery

### powershell
    
```
Get-WinEvent -LogName Security | where {($_.message -match "ParentImage.*rar.exe" -and $_.message -match "CommandLine.*.exe.*rar.exe") } | select TimeCreated,Id,RecordId,ProcessId,MachineName,Message,User,LogonId
Get-WinEvent -LogName Application | where {($_.message -match "ParentImage.*rar.exe" -and $_.message -match "CommandLine.*.exe.*rar.exe") } | select TimeCreated,Id,RecordId,ProcessId,MachineName,Message,User,LogonId

### powershell
```
Get-WinEvent -LogName Security -MaxEvents 1 -FilterXPath "*[System[EventID=4732]]" | ForEach-Object {
    if ($_.Message -match "netsh trace start" -and $_.Message -match "st" -and $_.Message -match "art") {
        Write-Host $_.Message -ForegroundColor Green
    }
}


```

(Index=WinEventLog Security (EventCode=4732) "netsh" (EventData) start st art | Table Message | reverse | head -3)

output_expected:
title: XSL Script Execution Via WMIC.EXE
id: 05c36dd6-79d6-4a9a-97da-3db20298ab2d
status: test
description: |
    Detects the execution of WMIC with the "format" flag to potentially load XSL files.
    Adversaries abuse this functionality to execute arbitrary files while potentially bypassing application whitelisting defenses.
    Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL) files are commonly used to describe the processing and rendering of data within XML files.
references:
    - https://github.com/redcanaryco/atomic-red-team/blob/f339e7da7d05f6057fdfcdd3742bfcf365fee2a9/atomics/T1220/T1220.md
author: Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community, Swachchhanda Shrawan Poudel
date: 2019-10-21
modified: 2024-03-05
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.t1220
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        Image|endswith: '\wmic.exe'
        CommandLine|contains|windash: '-format'     # wmic process list -FORMAT /? or wmic process list /FORMAT /?
    filter_main_known_format:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'Format:List'
            - 'Format:htable'
            - 'Format:hform'
            - 'Format:table'
            - 'Format:mof'
            - 'Format:value'
            - 'Format:rawxml'
            - 'Format:xml'
            - 'Format:csv'
    condition: selection and not 1 of filter_main_*
falsepositives:
    - WMIC.exe FP depend on scripts and administrative methods used in the monitored environment.
    - Static format arguments - https://petri.com/command-line-wmi-part-3
level: medium
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\wmic -format Format:List Format:htable Format:hform Format:table Format:mof Format:value Format:rawxml Format:xml Format:csv

### Response:
Potentially Vulnerable to MS08-067 (Shell Injection Vulnerability)
title: Potentially Vulnerable to MS08-067 (Shell Injection Vulnerability)
id: 1cc58e9c-703f-4675-a3aa-10978d36d37a
status: test
description: |
    Detects execution of wmic with various potential formatting options that can be used to execute commands.
    This technique has been used by adversaries to execute PowerShell code within a CommandPrompt environment.
    A number of tools within the Microsoft Framework Components (MFC) package have been abused to execute code in
    various languages within the shell via the command line tool - "wmic".

title: New PowerShell CIM Provider Registered
id: e82492c2-a68f-4101-9c50-3469b11a7bf9
status: test
description: |
    An adversary may abuse the "Register-CimProvider" PowerShell cmdlet in order to register a new CIM provider for the purposes of proxying PowerShell calls.
    CIM providers provide access to the objects exposed by a particular software product or service via a special data-transfer mechanism called Common Information Model (CIM).
    These objects are typically stored in database files which reside in a specified directory or UNC path.
    By registering a new provider, an adversary can use PowerShell to proxy commands to their intended destination.
    Attackers may use this technique to proxy access to Remote Desktop Services, Web applications, and other services.
references:
    - https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/OtherMsbins/Cimreg/
    - https://thedfirreport.com/2020/08/11/mechagent-a-powerful-lolbas-variant/

Detects the use of "Invoke-WebRequest" to download files. This is often abused to download malware.
This rule is designed to find suspicious use of the "Invoke-WebRequest" cmdlet to download files.
This could be indicative of a potential attacker attempting to download malware.

The rule filters on the "Invoke-WebRequest" cmdlet, and the "IRM" and "Invoke" strings, which are used as flags in legitimate web request.

id: 5da6b164-9f17-4076-b951-b8d2f509e612
status: test
description: |
    Detects execution of a Microsoft Browser Helper Objects (MSHTA) via the CreateObject method of Windows Script Host (WScript) in order to start and hide a window.
    Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Browser Helper Objects to hide and start their malicious JavaScript or VBScript code.
    A common method of hiding a browser window is to use the Window.close method in conjunction with the "Mshta" command to start a MSHTML helper (Mshta.exe) process.
    MSHTA will execute the specified HTML file and then terminate itself.

recommendation:
    - Anomaly-based detection
    - Set Mshta.exe as the default browser
    - Use a managed browser (Internet Explorer, Microsoft Edge, etc) to reduce the number of potential attacks that can be used
    - Configure all browsers to disable ActiveX and scripting
    - Preferably use a different non-default browser such as Firefox or Chrome to avoid potentially triggering malicious web content
    - Prevent Microsoft Internet Explorer from running by using Group Policy or registry keys
    - Apply patches that fix potential security vulnerabilities in Internet Explorer
    - Turn off the Internet Explorer Enhanced Security Configuration by using Group Policy or registry keys
    - Enable the  "Do not allow script or activeX controls to run" and "Turn off script debugging" flags in the registry
    - Do not use Windows Internet Explorer
    - Ensure the browser is up-to-date
    - Ensure the browser's cache is kept at minimum size
    - Enable the "Protected Mode" settings on Microsoft Internet Explorer to block potentially malicious websites from loading
    - Enable "SmartScreen Filter" and "SmartScreen Block Untrusted" to prevent the user from visiting potentially malicious websites
    - Ensure Microsoft Internet Explorer extensions are disabled
    - Ensure the "Enable First Run Customization" flag is not set
    - Ensure Internet Explorer is installed only on necessary systems and set the "Hide MSHTML" flag to prevent Internet Explorer' from starting when the system boots up.
    - Ensure the "Run" flag is not set for the Microsoft Internet Explorer application's executable (IExplore.exe)
    - Use a browser other than Internet Explorer such as Firefox or Chrome
    - Avoid loading external or potentially malicious content into Internet Explorer
    - Limit access of Internet Explorer to a set of trusted websites
    - Do not allow Internet Explorer to run as administrator
    - Restrict Internet Explorer's access to data stored in the user's profile
    - Enable the "Disable LLMNR and N

input: \bitsadmin.exe bitsadmin.exe /SetNotifyCmdLine %COMSPEC% cmd.exe regsvr32.exe -addfile http: https: ftp: ftps:
output_expected:
title: Monitoring For Persistence Via BITS
id: b9cbbc17-d00d-4e3d-a827-b06d03d2380d
status: test
description: |
    BITS will allow you to schedule a command to execute after a successful download to notify you that the job is finished.
    When the job runs on the system the command specified in the BITS job will be executed.
    This can be abused by actors to create a backdoor within the system and for persistence.
    It will be chained in a BITS job to schedule the download of malware/additional binaries and execute the program after being downloaded.
references:
    - https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/10/kegtap-and-singlemalt-with-a-ransomware-chaser.html
    - http://0xthem.blogspot.com/2014/03/t-emporal-persistence-with-and-schtasks.html
    - https://isc.sans.edu/diary/Wipe+the+drive+Stealthy+Malware+Persistence+Mechanism+-+Part+1/15394
author: Sreeman
date: 2020-10-29
modified: 2024-01-25
tags:
    - attack.defense-evasion
    - attack.t1197
logsource:
    product: windows
    category: process_creation
detection:
    selection_img:
        - Image|endswith: '\bitsadmin.exe'
        - OriginalFileName: 'bitsadmin.exe'
    selection_cli_notify_1:
        CommandLine|contains: '/SetNotifyCmdLine'
    selection_cli_notify_2:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - '%COMSPEC%'
            - 'cmd.exe'
            - 'regsvr32.exe'
    selection_cli_add_1:
        CommandLine|contains: '/Addfile'
    selection_cli_add_2:
        CommandLine|contains:
            - 'http:'
            - 'https:'
            - 'ftp:'
            - 'ftps:'
    condition: selection_img and (all of selection_cli_notify_* or all of selection_cli_add_*)
falsepositives:
    - Unknown
level: medium
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\bitsadmin.exe bitsadmin.exe /SetNotifyCmdLine %COMSPEC% cmd.exe regsvr32.exe -addfile http: https: ftp: ftps:

### Response:

Rarely seen when using legitimate software or even browser bookmarks

    When a file is opened, the default program used to open the file (also called the file association or handler) is checked. An attacker might abuse Rundll32.exe in order to execute malicious scripts
For example, an attacker might abuse Rundll32.exe in order to execute malicious scripts in order to hide a process by calling the window.close() method in order to close it.
Rundll32.exe might also be used to load and execute DLL files.

id: 9b558d9a-d204-44b2-902b-0572c7937d0c
status: test
description: |
    Detects potential command line suspicious patterns used by adversaries.
    This includes "ping"ing domains in order to discover IP addresses, using "copy" as a launcher in order to avoid SIEM alerting, and using flags like "-n" to avoid the output to be shown on the screen.
    Adversaries can use these techniques to hide and bypass defenses and to avoid leaving clear event log trails.
references:
    - https://github.com/redcanaryco/atomic-red-team/blob/f339e7da7b0e946fcdab4da24d76ccd39a1b1e1/atomics/T1059.002/T1059.002.md

    product: windows

            - 'ping'
            - 'copy'

            - 'cmd.exe'
    selection_modified:
        CommandLine|contains|any:
            - 'ping'
            - 'copy'

    condition: selection_original or selection_modified
falsepositives:

title: HackTool - KrbRelay Execution
id: e96253b8-6b3b-4f90-9e59-3b24b99cf9b4

detection:

    selection_cli_1:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - ' -spn '
            - ' -clsid '
            - ' -rbcd '
    selection_cli_2:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - 'shadowcred'
            - 'clsid'
            - 'spn'
    selection_cli_3:
        CommandLine|contains|all:
            - 'spn '
            - 'session '
            - 'clsid '
    condition: 1 of selection_*
falsepositives:
    - Unlikely
level: high
output_model:
### Instruction:
Write Sigma rule to detect payload:

### Input:
\RemoteKrbRelay.exe RemoteKrbRelay.exe -clsid -target \"-victim\" -smb --smbkeyword interactive secrets service-add -rbcd -cn --computername -chp -chpPass -chpUser -addgroupmember -group -groupuser

### Response:
drop Database "db_name" ;
GO
create table table_name (col_name varchar(MAX) NOT NULL);
insert into table_name values ('value');
GO
select * from table_name where col_name='value';

### Detection:
This payload can be used to steal AD credentials or dump hashes from a remote AD.

* https://www.cybereason.com/blog/hacking-active-directory-with-lolbas
* https://pentestlab.blog/2022/01/04/hacking-active-directory-with-lolbas/

related:
    - id: b59280a5-94c4-424d-846f-4e9374e6833f
      type: derived
status: test
description: |
    Detects suspicious processes that start immediately after the "cmd" process or processes known as "run by cmd".
    Attackers might abuse this to execute arbitrary commands immediately after the "cmd" process starts. 
    A "run by cmd" means that this process started by "cmd" process. 
    This might help in launching malicious processes to bypass defenses like UAC, Antivirus and other security products.
references:
    - https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2022/10/05/attackers-abuse-cmd-exe-to-execute-arbitrary-commands-in-suspicious-processes/
    - https://threatpost.com/microsoft-security-bulletin-vulnerability-10068655/

(OriginalFileName="BrowserCore.dll") (Image="BrowserCore\" type:file)
